entry.title: HTL-Saalfelden
entry.summary: A World Without Computer Science is Unimaginable! We offer you a comprehensive education in all aspects of software development, network technology, databases, artificial…
entry.content:
A World Without Computer Science is Unimaginable!

We offer you a comprehensive education in all aspects of software development, network technology, databases, artificial intelligence, as well as business management and project management. After graduating from the HTL for Computer Science, an incredibly wide range of career opportunities awaits you.

Computer Architecture and Operating Systems

How is a computer structured? What tasks does an operating system perform? How do I install applications? How do interfaces work? This course teaches the foundational principles of computer science.

Programming and Software Engineering

This subject covers the core competencies of a modern computer science education. It begins with essential programming techniques and progresses to real-world tasks, guiding students through all stages of software development using current platforms.

Databases

Databases form the backbone of countless applications. Students learn to develop, program, and implement various types of databases and practice these skills through hands-on projects.

Network Systems and Cybersecurity

This area focuses on the design and implementation of communication networks. Students plan and create computer networks using suitable components such as LAN cables, switches, routers, firewalls, and WLAN systems. Practical lessons cover how to install, configure, and secure network services like web servers.

Web Programming and Mobile Computing

Learn to develop websites and create your own apps across various application domains, such as games, sports, and the Internet of Things.

Data Science and Artificial Intelligence

“Big Data” and “Artificial Intelligence” are the key topics of this subject, preparing students for cutting-edge fields.

Business Management and Leadership

This course provides essential knowledge about the operational areas of businesses, their organization, and management.

Empowering Women in Computer Science

For girls interested in technology and seeking careers beyond traditional roles, computer science offers an exciting path. With opportunities in all areas of technology—from game design to advanced databases—the field is especially attractive. This education equips students for the workforce, offering excellent pay and growth opportunities.

IT NOW, IT IS THE FUTURE, CODING THE FUTURE

Career Opportunities and Fields of Application

Graduates of Computer Science are qualified for a wide range of technical and engineering roles, including:

  • Application and Software Development
  • Application and System Programming
  • Software Engineering
  • Information Systems Organization
  • Database Design and Programming
  • Data Protection and Cybersecurity
  • Application Design
  • Project Management
  • System Analysis and Requirements Engineering
  • IT Consulting
  • System Administration and Management
  • IT Training
  • Independent Entrepreneurship

The future is waiting for you—become a part of it!

entry.title: UNIFITS
entry.summary: Our Diploma Project: Invoice Archive for Unifits For our diploma project, my colleague and I are developing a web-based invoice archive system for…
entry.content:
Our Diploma Project: Invoice Archive for Unifits

For our diploma project, my colleague and I are developing a web-based invoice archive system for the company Unifits. This system is designed to streamline the internal handling of invoices, providing an intuitive and efficient solution for managing invoice-related tasks.

The Vision In collaboration with Unifits, we aim to build a tool that simplifies invoice management through features like:

Import and Export of Invoices: Seamlessly adding and retrieving invoice data. Sorting and Categorization: Organizing invoices for better accessibility. Management and Tracking: Monitoring invoices throughout their lifecycle. The Architecture The project is built using a modern web-based architecture, including:

Frontend: A user-friendly interface that enables employees to interact with the system efficiently. Backend: Handles data processing, business logic, and integration with external systems. Database: Stores all invoice records securely, ensuring reliability and scalability. We are leveraging best practices in web development to ensure the system is robust, responsive, and future-proof.

The Development Process The project follows an agile methodology, breaking down tasks into iterative sprints for constant progress and feedback. Some of the key steps include:

Requirement Analysis: Understanding Unifits’ needs and translating them into functional requirements. Design and Prototyping: Creating a mockup of the interface and defining the database schema. Implementation: Writing code for both the frontend and backend systems, integrating them seamlessly. Testing and Refinement: Rigorous testing to ensure the system meets usability and reliability standards. Current Status The project is still under development, and we’re working closely with Unifits to ensure the final system aligns with their expectations. Further updates, including a detailed feature list and implementation details, will be shared upon completion.

What Makes This Project Exciting Real-World Impact: The system addresses a genuine business need, enhancing invoice handling at Unifits. Skill Development: We’re gaining hands-on experience in full-stack web development, database management, and collaborative teamwork. Collaboration: Partnering with a real company provides invaluable insights into professional workflows and client communication. Looking Forward We’re excited about the progress we’ve made and look forward to delivering a finished product that adds value to Unifits’ operations. This diploma project is not only a significant milestone in our education but also a stepping stone toward a professional career in software development. Stay tuned for more details once the project is complete!

entry.title: LEVEL UP, Salzburg 2024
entry.summary: The second edition of LEVEL UP – The Gaming Festival took place on June 29 and 30 at the Salzburg Exhibition Center, drawing…
entry.content:
The second edition of LEVEL UP – The Gaming Festival took place on June 29 and 30 at the Salzburg Exhibition Center, drawing around 10,000 enthusiastic visitors. With a vibrant mix of eSports tournaments, interactive experiences, fascinating exhibitors, and impressive cosplay performances, the event offered something for everyone. After this successful weekend, we’re already looking forward to the next edition on June 28 and 29, 2025!

Mainstage: Spotlight on eSports and Diversity

The mainstage of LEVEL UP 2024 was the hotspot for eSports fans and professionals alike. High-caliber tournaments captivated the audience, featuring thrilling competitions in games like Rocket League, Counter-Strike 2, and Super Smash Bros. The electrifying atmosphere made the mainstage the festival’s central highlight.

A standout feature on the mainstage was the SheRivals: Queens of Austria show match. This unique League of Legends tournament featured female teams from NNO Prime and SK Gaming, marking a bold statement for greater diversity and visibility for women in eSports.

Lena Braito, project manager of LEVEL UP, emphasized the importance of inclusion:
“At LEVEL UP, we place great value on diversity. That’s why, for the first time, we organized an all-female tournament this year in collaboration with our long-standing partners, Morekats Gaming. Our goal is to inspire young women and girls and challenge traditional gender roles.”

Excitement and Fun on the Raiffeisen Club Community Stage

The Raiffeisen Club Community Stage featured a range of interactive programs where visitors could actively participate. Highlights included the LudeCat, where participants competed in indie games in four-player matches. At Game2Help – Beat the Pro, daring challengers faced off against Super Smash pro and YouTuber Luigikid, showcasing their skills. For every exceptional performance against the pro, €200 was added to the donation pool for Letsplay4Charity. Visitors also showcased their gaming and pop culture knowledge during The Amazing Nerdquiz – LEVEL UP Edition.

The stage even allowed attendees to get a taste of the spotlight themselves!

Streaming for a Good Cause

The Letsplay4Charity livestream was another massive success. Popular streamers gathered live from the festival to raise money for charitable causes through their Twitch streams. Over 281,000 viewers tuned in and donated directly during the broadcast.

In addition, the Beat the Pro Challenge from Game2Help contributed to the charity drive, helping raise a remarkable total of €11,000 for various causes.

Indie Games, Retro Gaming, and More in the Gaming Zone

The Gaming Zone was an exciting hub featuring exhibitors and teams showcasing innovative offerings. Highlights included an escape room by Salzburg AG, a digger simulator by Porr, and sim racing at the Red Bull Gaming Ground. Companies like BRZ, W&H, and Axess also used the event to recruit talent.

The Indie Games Area, presented by FH Salzburg, attracted visitors interested in the creativity and innovation of independent developers. Thirty game creators showcased their projects, offering attendees a glimpse into the world of unique, off-the-beaten-path games.

Adjacent to the Gaming Zone, the Retro Area was a paradise for fans of classic games, featuring iconic titles, pinball machines, and vintage gaming consoles.

From Art to Action: Beyond Screens

The Artist Alley was the go-to place for fans of creative craftsmanship. Featuring hand-made artwork, posters, jewelry, and fan merchandise, this lively zone celebrated the artistic side of gaming culture. Next door, the Tabletop Area offered a cozy spot for strategy, board, and card game enthusiasts to try out new games or join tournaments.

For those seeking action, the Action Area delivered thrilling experiences. Visitors tested their skills on KTM minibikes, engaged in tactical matches of laser tag, or had fun in Bubble Soccer—bouncing around in giant inflatable balls. VR matches blurred the lines between virtual and real, adding an extra layer of excitement.

Looking Ahead to LEVEL UP 2025

Alexander Kribus, Managing Director of the Salzburg Exhibition Center, expressed his delight:
“LEVEL UP exceeded all expectations this year with its diversity and interactive programming. The positive feedback and enthusiasm of the visitors made the event a phenomenal success. We are already looking forward to continuing this momentum next year.”

Mark your calendars! LEVEL UP 2025 is happening on June 28 and 29, and we can’t wait to see you there!

entry.title: eurofunk
entry.summary: 6 Weeks at Eurofunk: A Developer’s Journey in Collaboration and Growth This summer, I had the incredible opportunity to spend six weeks at…
entry.content:
6 Weeks at Eurofunk: A Developer’s Journey in Collaboration and Growth

This summer, I had the incredible opportunity to spend six weeks at Eurofunk, a leading company known for its innovative contributions to public safety systems and services. Joining their team of talented developers, I was immersed in a professional agile development environment where collaboration, learning, and problem-solving took center stage.

A Day in the Life

At Eurofunk, every day started with a daily stand-up. These quick team meetings fostered open communication, allowing us to share progress, tackle blockers, and align on priorities. I was also part of sprint retrospectives and reviews, where we analyzed what went well, identified areas for improvement, and showcased our work. These agile practices not only enhanced team productivity but also helped me understand how large-scale projects are managed in a structured yet adaptable manner.

The Project: Mapping Automation with Street Data

During my time at Eurofunk, I worked alongside other interns on a project that combined technical innovation and teamwork.

The Goal

Our task was to develop a solution that automated the process of scraping and modeling street map data for one of Eurofunk’s services. This involved:

  • Gathering data from various online sources.
  • Processing and transforming it into a usable format.
  • Creating a scalable pipeline that integrated seamlessly into the company’s existing systems.

The Process

  • Research: Understanding the web scraping tools and APIs we needed for the project.
  • Design: Collaborating with teammates to draft workflows and architecture for the data pipeline.
  • Development: Writing and testing code while adhering to Eurofunk’s coding standards.
  • Integration: Ensuring the automated process delivered accurate, structured data to the service.

The Learning Curve

This project was both challenging and rewarding. I learned:

  • How to manipulate geospatial data effectively.
  • Best practices in writing maintainable, scalable code for automation.
  • The importance of testing and documentation in professional software development.

The Team Experience

Working at Eurofunk was more than just tackling technical challenges—it was about being part of a highly skilled and supportive team. The developers were not only mentors but also collaborators, always willing to share their expertise and provide guidance. Their encouragement helped me grow both as a developer and as a team player.

Key Takeaways

Technical Growth

  • Learned to work with web scraping tools and geospatial data.
  • Gained hands-on experience with agile development practices.
  • Strengthened my understanding of large-scale system integration.

Professional Development

  • Participated in structured workflows that emphasized collaboration and communication.
  • Improved problem-solving skills by tackling real-world challenges.
  • Experienced firsthand the dynamics of a large, well-organized company.

Reflections

My time at Eurofunk was a defining moment in my journey as a developer. It showed me the value of teamwork, the power of structure in achieving ambitious goals, and the thrill of seeing a project come to life.

I’m incredibly grateful to the Eurofunk team for welcoming me and allowing me to contribute to their mission. It was a privilege to learn from such talented professionals and to see how cutting-edge solutions are built in a real-world environment.

Looking ahead, I’m excited to apply what I’ve learned and continue growing in the field of software development. Thank you, Eurofunk, for an unforgettable experience!

entry.title: Allegiance
entry.summary: My Role: Procedural World Generation The Challenge Creating a world that felt alive, varied, and endless was no small feat. The goal was…
entry.content:
My Role: Procedural World Generation

The Challenge

Creating a world that felt alive, varied, and endless was no small feat. The goal was to generate a procedurally infinite map that seamlessly combined:

  • Topography: Mountains, valleys, and plateaus.
  • Biomes: Desert, forest, tundra, and more.
  • Features: Lakes, rivers, and villages.

The Solution

To achieve this, I implemented procedural generation using Perlin noise and additional algorithms for layering and refinement.

  1. Noise Maps

    • Used Perlin noise to generate foundational maps for elevation, humidity, and temperature.
    • Combined these parameters to define biomes dynamically. For example:
      • High elevation + low temperature = snowy mountains.
      • Low elevation + high humidity = swamps.

  2. World Features

    • Added rivers and lakes by calculating water flow from higher elevations.
    • Randomly placed villages in hospitable areas based on temperature and terrain accessibility.

  3. Seamless Tiling

    • Implemented chunk-based world generation to ensure infinite expansion as the player explored.
    • Used optimization techniques like object pooling to maintain performance.

  4. Visual Feedback

    • Integrated pixel-art assets to represent the terrain and features.
    • Biomes were visually distinct, with unique vegetation, structures, and NPCs.

Team Contributions

While I focused on procedural generation, my teammates worked on:

  • Combat and Crafting Systems: Adding weapons, enemies, and resource gathering.
  • Quest and NPC Design: Developing a narrative and interactions to keep players engaged.
  • Game UI and Controls: Ensuring the game was intuitive and fun to play.

Collaboration was key, and we often reviewed and integrated our work to ensure the final product was cohesive and polished.

What I Learned

This project was a massive learning experience. I gained:

  • Technical Skills

    • Deep understanding of Perlin noise and procedural generation techniques.
    • Optimization strategies for performance in large, dynamic game worlds.

  • Teamwork

    • Working in a team taught me to communicate effectively and balance individual contributions with collective goals.

  • Creativity in Problem-Solving

    • Turning a complex system like procedural world generation into a functional and enjoyable game element required both logic and creativity.

The Result

The final game was a hit among our peers and teachers. Players could wander through stunning biomes, interact with NPCs, and uncover hidden treasures. The seamless transitions between environments and the infinite exploration made the game feel expansive and alive.

Reflections

Looking back, I’m incredibly proud of what our team achieved. Creating an infinite world from scratch and watching players immerse themselves in it was an unforgettable experience. This project sparked my interest in game development and procedural systems, inspiring me to explore these areas further.

Unity has always been a powerful tool, but this project showed me how much can be accomplished with teamwork, creativity, and a passion for the craft.

entry.title: Linsinger Vermessung
entry.summary: The Challenge Modern businesses rely heavily on stable and secure network systems, and Linsinger Vermessung was no exception. However, their existing network setup,…
entry.content:
The Challenge

Modern businesses rely heavily on stable and secure network systems, and Linsinger Vermessung was no exception. However, their existing network setup, while functional, needed a detailed review to ensure scalability, efficiency, and documentation for future maintenance. My task was to:

  • Map out the network infrastructure: Identify and document all network components, including servers, LAN, WAN, switches, and other devices.
  • Evaluate the server rooms: Assess the organization, connectivity, and cooling systems in their server rooms.
  • Propose improvements: Recommend practical upgrades or organizational changes to enhance reliability and performance.

The Process

1. Network Mapping and Documentation

I began by systematically mapping the network. Using tools and manual checks, I documented:

  • Physical connections: cables, switches, and routers.
  • Logical connections: IP configurations, subnets, and access points.
  • Devices and services: Servers, workstations, and their respective roles within the network.

Creating a visual network map not only clarified the existing setup but also highlighted areas that could benefit from optimization.

2. Server Room Assessment

The server rooms were a critical focus. I evaluated:

  • Cable management: Identifying areas where tangled cables or unclear labeling could lead to inefficiencies.
  • Cooling systems: Checking airflow and ensuring that overheating wasn’t a potential issue.
  • Hardware organization: Reviewing rack layouts to identify opportunities for better utilization of space.

3. Proposing Improvements

Based on my findings, I provided a set of actionable recommendations:

  • Enhanced cable management: Suggested labeling systems and rerouting for clearer identification and troubleshooting.
  • Upgraded network devices: Highlighted outdated hardware that could be replaced for better performance.
  • Documentation updates: Delivered a comprehensive network manual, including diagrams and configuration details, for internal use.

Results

By the end of the week, I presented my findings and recommendations to the IT department. While some improvements, like better labeling, were implemented immediately, others were added to their long-term roadmap. The visual documentation I created became a reference tool for their ongoing network management, streamlining future maintenance and expansion efforts.

Takeaways

This project reinforced my skills in:

  • Network analysis: Mapping and documenting complex systems efficiently.
  • Problem-solving: Identifying and addressing gaps in infrastructure.
  • Communication: Translating technical findings into actionable insights for the team.

Though short, this experience at Linsinger Vermessung was incredibly rewarding. It allowed me to apply my knowledge in a real-world setting and contribute meaningfully to a company’s technical operations.

If your business is considering a network review or upgrade, remember—sometimes a fresh set of eyes can make all the difference!

entry.title: itxpert
entry.summary: Hands-On Tech: My Experience at ITExpert This summer, I had the privilege of working at ITExpert, a local electronics and hardware retail and…
entry.content:
Hands-On Tech: My Experience at ITExpert

This summer, I had the privilege of working at ITExpert, a local electronics and hardware retail and repair shop. Despite being a small operation with just three employees, ITExpert’s commitment to solving all things tech-related made it a bustling hub of activity. Over the course of three weeks, I dove headfirst into the fast-paced world of hardware repair, software installation, and technical support.

The Scope of My Work

At ITExpert, no two days were the same. My responsibilities were diverse, covering everything from assembling PCs to remote support. Here’s a closer look at what I did:

1. Building and Repairing PCs

  • Assembly and disassembly: I built systems from scratch and dismantled others for repairs. From carefully installing CPUs and GPUs to reseating RAM and troubleshooting hardware faults, I gained a deeper appreciation for the intricacies of computer assembly.
  • Diagnostics and fixes: Whether it was a power issue, a faulty motherboard, or upgrading components, I tackled hardware problems hands-on.

2. Laptop and Desktop Setup

  • Client system boot-ups: Preparing newly purchased PCs and laptops for customer use was a regular task. This included installing operating systems, running initial setup scripts, and optimizing system settings.
  • Satellite setups: I configured satellite devices for customers, ensuring they integrated seamlessly into their existing networks.

3. Software Installation and Security

  • Security software: I installed and configured antivirus and other protective measures to safeguard client data.
  • Scripts and updates: Running installation scripts and ensuring systems were up-to-date was a crucial part of preparing machines for customers.

4. Printer Repairs

Printers are notorious for their quirks, and I spent a fair share of time troubleshooting them. From paper jams to connectivity issues, I ensured these machines were up and running smoothly.

5. AnyDesk Remote Support

Providing quick fixes remotely via AnyDesk was another facet of my role. It was a valuable exercise in problem-solving under pressure and communicating effectively with clients.

What I Learned

Technical Skills

  • Hardware expertise: Hands-on work with components like CPUs, GPUs, and motherboards expanded my hardware knowledge significantly.
  • Software optimization: I honed my ability to install, configure, and secure systems efficiently.
  • Troubleshooting: The diversity of issues I faced taught me how to think critically and adapt quickly.

Soft Skills

  • Client communication: Explaining technical concepts in simple terms and managing client expectations was crucial in this customer-facing role.
  • Team collaboration: Working in a small team of three meant wearing multiple hats and ensuring smooth coordination.

Reflections

My time at ITExpert was a crash course in real-world IT problem-solving. The shop’s small size gave me exposure to every aspect of its operations, from direct client interaction to deep dives into hardware repair. It was a dynamic environment that kept me on my toes and made every day a learning experience.

If there’s one takeaway from my time there, it’s this: No issue is too small, and every problem solved is a step toward greater expertise. A huge thank-you to the ITExpert team for the opportunity to contribute and grow!

Looking forward to tackling even bigger challenges in the tech world. 🚀

entry.title: LEVEL UP, Salzburg, 2022
entry.summary: The second edition of LEVEL UP – The Gaming Festival took place on June 29 and 30 at the Salzburg Exhibition Center, drawing…
entry.content:

entry.title: BG/BRG/BORG St. Johann
entry.summary: Marine Biology Week 19/20 School Year 19/20 – MINT Classes The 4th-grade students of the science-focused branch spent a week in Croatia. On…
entry.content:
Marine Biology Week 19/20

School Year 19/20 – MINT Classes

The 4th-grade students of the science-focused branch spent a week in Croatia.

On July 2, 2019, the two science classes, 4AR and 4BR, departed from St. Johann heading to Croatia. On Monday, students picked up their snorkeling gear and tried on their wetsuits for the first time to ensure a proper fit.

Day 1: Getting Started

Well-equipped, the two classes began their first project day separately on Tuesday.

  • 4AR:
    The class boarded a boat that took them to the uninhabited island of Plavnik after an hour’s journey. Upon arrival, they received an introduction to snorkeling before diving into the sea to explore marine life. Among the discoveries were starfish, sea cucumbers, and a variety of fish. In the afternoon, the group moved to a plateau, where they caught the native Apulian tarantula and found other creatures such as a praying mantis.

  • 4BR:
    This class spent their first day snorkeling in a bay. In the afternoon, they participated in a scavenger hunt, where they discovered, caught, and in some cases, even tasted various organisms. Each group presented their findings in detail to the rest of the class through small presentations.

Day 2: Switching Programs

On Wednesday, the two classes swapped activities. The only difference was that the 4AR also had the opportunity to explore an abandoned hotel.

Day 3: A Shared Adventure

On Thursday, both classes traveled together to another bay for their final snorkeling session. In the afternoon, they focused on various activities, such as collecting waste to contribute to environmental conservation.

Evening and Departure

That evening, everyone went on a group trip to the town of Krk. On Friday, after breakfast, the students headed back to Austria.
